results.title: Spotlight on Australian Ballet
results.creator_credit: Doc K Sternberg, Geoff Powell, Loch Townsend, A Anderson and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: A survey of the development of ballet in Australia. The contribution made by such enthusiasts as Edouard Borovansky, Helene Kirsova, Laurel Martyn, Dorothy Stevenson, and other Australian dancers in training and encouraging aspiring dancers, and the untiring efforts of the various corps des ballets, the majority of whom have had to fit in their clases and training, and in many cases, their actual performances, after normal working hours, are presented as the background to the status of ballet in Australia in 1948. Narrated by John Bushelle.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Doc K Sternberg, Geoff Powell, Loch Townsend, A Anderson and Australian National Film Board

results.title: My family
results.creator_credit: Malcolm Dotoi, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: To Malcolm Dotoi, his family includes what he would call his extended family, his cousins and grandfather. They provide support, guidance and inspiration and have helped him to develop into a youth leader. His grandfather, a tribal elder, has taught Malcolm about his connection to the land and to the spiritual world and how all these things have contributed to who Malcolm is today.

results.title: Spiceworld: the movie
results.creator_credit: Bob Spiers, Barnaby Thompson, Uri Fruchtmann and Fragile Films
results.brief_description: A thriller with a little romance and a lot of comedy, “Spiceworld” chronicles the five crazy days leading to the Spice Girls’ first live concert at the Royal Albert Hall. Photojournalists follow as they travel from press conferences to practice sessions to photo shoots, passing London landmarks in the comfort of their tardis Spicebus and emerging into a musical cascade of colour, trendy clothes and blinding flashbulbs. Exploring the trials and tribulations of their global fame, “Spiceworld” takes a satirical stab at the media giants and commercial junkies who relentlessly compete to manufacture the girls’ success or demise. Cast includes The Spice Girls, Richard E. Grant, Alan Cumming, George Wendt, Claire Rushbrook and Roger Moore.
